Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Interventions to Reduce Opioid Use After Orthopaedic Surgery

Participants.evidence: Eligible studies included adult patients who underwent orthopaedic surgery

Intervention.evidence: Multimodal analgesic interventions resulted in a lower mean daily opioid dose compared to placebo/no intervention/usual care or active control

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the effectiveness of various interventions to reduce opioid consumption post-surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the mean daily dose of opioid analgesics in morphine milligram equivalents (MME) at 1â€“3 months post-randomisation.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Multimodal analgesic interventions resulted in a lower mean daily opioid dose compared to placebo/no intervention/usual care or active control in the medium term.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 17 studies, with no significant differences between groups.
